Open Thread 60.5

Posted on October 16, 2016 by Scott Alexander

This is the twice-weekly hidden open thread. Post about anything you want, ask random questions, whatever.

This entry was posted in Uncategorized and tagged open. Bookmark the permalink.
← More Hardball Debate Questions
The Moral Of The Story →

764 Responses to Open Thread 60.5

Reverse order
  1. IrishDude says:
    October 19, 2016 at 12:33 pm

    Politico provides a fascinating peak inside the Clinton campaign through wikileaks Podesta emails: http://www.politico.com/live-blog-updates/2016/10/john-podesta-hillary-clinton-emails-wikileaks-000011

    As one example I found interesting, they had 11 people work on one tweet about Puerto Rico. The tight messaging and thorough vetting of every.single.thing. that Clinton puts out gave me a new lens into campaigns, which I previously hadn’t put much thought into. A whole of other interesting things are in the emails.

  2. TMB says:
    October 18, 2016 at 6:26 pm

    Did anyone here ever play Birthright: The Gorgan’s Alliance?

    You play as one of the lords in a fractured Empire, initially competing with your rivals for petty gains, then having to contend with a massive (and incredibly difficult to defeat) invasion from the Gorgan.

    It was a really remarkable game. In many ways poorly made, but the strength of the setting made it worthwhile.
    When I finally (after many failed attempts) managed to beat back the Gorgan’s legions and launch a counter invasion, marching to the relief of the Dwarfs of Baruk-Azhik, taking back the burned elf-lands, crushing the Gorgan’s evil allies in the great battle for Mur-Kilad, before the final, decisive battle outside the walls of his dread fortress – well, it was really, really satisfying.

    So, are there any other games that have used a similar setting? Fractured kingdom must unite behind one great leader to prevent destruction from evil invading force (and the evil invading force doing everything it can to undermine attempts at unity)?

    • Dr Dealgood says:
      October 18, 2016 at 6:43 pm

      Seconding this request, but focused a bit more on the gameplay aspect of it. I’d never heard of that game until now but it looks great.

      I’ve always liked the idea of a strategy game where you play from the viewpoint of an actual character in the world. Mount and Blade is the closest to that idea I’ve ever seen. It lacks any of the plot aspects TMB is talking about but if you want to go from some random guy with a spear to a lord riding at the head of armies it’s a good one.

      • Stefan Drinic says:
        October 19, 2016 at 9:14 am

        Kingdom under Fire: the Crusaders would be my own response to both you and the OP, but the curse of system progression makes it regrettably unplayable by now.

        More snarkily, I could point to Shogun 2: Total War, and argue that it’s this kind of thing in reverse; you are the invader against whom people unite, in that case.

      • tcd says:
        October 19, 2016 at 12:00 pm

        The next installment, Mount and Blade: Bannerlord, claims to address some of the story elements lacking in the previous games. They have demo’d side events like leaving part of your army in a town to run a crime racket and a few other things like that. It is also gorgeous.

        • Dr Dealgood says:
          October 19, 2016 at 12:22 pm

          I didn’t mind the lack of a story structure in Warband though. If anything it seemed like one of it’s charms.

          Mount and Blade felt a lot like an OSR in that respect. “The story” was your story, the story of what you did in the game. Things matter more when you know that they’re the results of your actions, and it could have gone differently. You can fake that like Mass Effect did but self-directed exploration works a lot better IMO.

    • Lumifer says:
      October 18, 2016 at 8:46 pm

      Warlock: Master of the Arcane? You fight relatively weak rivals, and then (optionally) you get an invasion of BAMFs.

    • Anonymous says:
      October 19, 2016 at 1:32 am

      That sounds like a game in a similar vein to Sengoku Rance. It’s a strategy/roleplaying/anime porn game where you’re trying to unify a fantasy analogue of Japan, and then midway through the Demon Army shows up (spoilers) and you have to fight them. It is also a really remarkable game, in a lot of ways.

    • Jugemu Chousuke says:
      October 19, 2016 at 7:47 am

      Warhammer: Total War follows this pattern. The human and dwarf factions are initially heavily divided, but are much more willing to unite when big-bad Archaon and his hordes of Chaos attack in mid-game (only to become more wary of each other again once the outside threat is defeated). (There are also other factions like the Orks that are less diplomatically inclined).

      It’s also a good game overall, though might be a bit overwhelming at first if you’re never played a Total War game before.

  3. Tekhno says:
    October 18, 2016 at 5:24 pm

    I’m making a another thread so not to veer off topic, but something someone said in the discussions above that made me want to discuss something else:

    @dragnubbit

    I also agree that Libertarians have a blind spot for initial conditions. They cannot be reset entirely (and attempts to do so would trigger social havoc and be counterproductive)

    That’s never stopped anyone!

    Just musing here, but I wonder if it’s possible to have a revolutionary right-libertarianism if you start with the NAP – where aggression against person and legitimately acquired property is disavowed – but then veer away from regular anarcho-capitalism by combining it with the position that no existing property is legitimate because all trades can be traced back to violent conquest before they can be traced back to legitimate mixing of labor with land.

    All existing property titles are then concluded to be invalid without violating anarcho-capitalism’s overall stance on property rights. All property then becomes unowned property and is transformed into property through occupancy and use. This would mean that workers would own the businesses they work in and renters would own the houses they live in, as the original title is assumed to have an illegitimate aggression based origin. This kind of hack of the ancap program would represent a halfway house between regular ancap and mutualism.

    Rothbard came the closest to this position when he was making appeals to the New Left about public Universities reverting to student ownership, even going as far to propose a cut-off point where private Universities would be considered illegitimate, at the point where at least 50% of their funding came from subsidization. No need to respect the “property” of the horse thief, Rothbard says.

    Go a little further with “left-Rothbardianism” and you can produce a revolutionary agenda against all existing title. It’s kind of arbitrary how far you tune the dial.

    You might say that you can’t show that if we walk backwards all existing property title was transferred through coercion at some point, but you can’t show that this isn’t the case either, and it seems to me that regular bogstandard anarcho-capitalism is running with the claim that all existing property should be treat as legitimate for expediencies sake’s. The problem is that the NAP hinges entirely on legitimacy, whereby property is absolute so long as it is gained through some standard of peaceful acquisition, and absolutely invalid if it is gained through violence. Since there are no magical machines which let us look back in time and determine these things, we have no way of knowing what property goes all the way back to peaceful construction uninterrupted, and what property was taken by force before subsequent trades.

    It’s therefore essentially arbitrary which side you choose. Since this is so, it’s surprising to me that more anarcho-capitalists haven’t chosen the resetist option. You can argue against this on the grounds of consequentialism and the chaos it would produce, but there are plenty of people willing to argue for chaos and violent revolution among the socialist anarchists. People can make a case for anything, so where are all the people making the case for reset based anarcho-capitalism?

    I’m not saying that it’s a good idea(it’s a terrible idea!), but why is this terrible idea so unpopular? There are plenty of anarcho-capitalists on the internet, and pretty much every single one of them (including the weird C4SS lefty lot) argues for the conservative option with regard to legitimacy. From the outside this looks like a completely arbitrary choice when considering there are also so many advocates for the position that no property is ever legitimate (socialists).

    • Dr Dealgood says:
      October 18, 2016 at 5:34 pm

      Because a big appeal of libertarianism in the real world, the reason I occasionally round myself off to a small-l libertarian despite being somewhat anti-capitalist, is being able to say “get off my lawn” to people hoping to abscond with your belongings. That holds whether they’re local hoods or IRS agents from Washington.

      Your posited position is to say “what do you mean your lawn?” and abscond with everyone’s belongings. Pretty much exactly the opposite position.

    • Anonymous says:
      October 18, 2016 at 6:36 pm

      I’ve always believed that libertarians are left-wing, but this is the first time I’ve ever seen any evidence that they’re right-wing. Pretty strong evidence.

    • Tekhno says:
      October 18, 2016 at 6:37 pm

      Because a big appeal of libertarianism in the real world

      But in the real world we also have plenty of people who want to smash capitalism and expropriate the expropriators. Through only a slight deviation on a totally arbitrary element of anarcho-capitalist theory, I think that I’ve demonstrated that you can proclaim a philosophy that aims at both expropriatory revolution and a free market society built upon the absolute sanctity of legitimate property rights (which is what anarcho-capitalism is already based upon; it is the legitimacy question that is left hanging and up for grabs).

      Your posited position is to say “what do you mean your lawn?” and abscond with everyone’s belongings.

      Usually, in anarcho-capitalism there is some theory about what counts for turning unowned property into private property. Various theories run from fencing stuff off to having to mix your labor with the land. It’s easy enough to add in the mutualist principle of occupancy and use and say that your lawn is yours because you use it. The new title going forwards would be established by you being the occupier, and since anarcho-capitalism posits defense agencies and arbitration services, we can assume as easily as we can under regular ancap that they would enforce that, and that going forwards you would possess a legitimate private property title to your land.

      The difference is that if you reset property back to being unowned then the people who would be least positioned to make new claims are absentee owners of all types; shareholders and single proprietors alike. The workers in a factory can by occupancy and use or “mixing of labor” then present a joint claim to equal share ownership.

      It’s basically just dialing up the argument Rothbard already made about subsidized private property to apply to all private property.

      • Dr Dealgood says:
        October 18, 2016 at 6:51 pm

        I guess I’m the wrong guy to ask.

        The NAP and all that stuff about mixing labor with things never did anything for me. It seems like the idea of natural rights: if you don’t take it too seriously it’s fine as a justification, but if you do it turns into an intellectual rabbit hole.

        I’m very deeply suspicious of any movement based on the principle of “all your stuff is up for grabs.” I don’t believe for one second that the folks divvying things up wouldn’t use it as an excuse to steal everything that wasn’t nailed down. Look at how privatization in Russia and the Eastern Bloc went.

      • Murphy says:
        October 19, 2016 at 9:41 am

        There’s also the geolibertarians who reject the “mixing with your labor” idea, tag line “you have the right to the fruits of your labor but your labor didn’t make the land”

        ie: jamming some fence posts into the ground around a plot doesn’t make the oil under it the fruits of your labor.

        As such land and the rights to the resources under it would be leased to bidders.
        Such a system leaves room for a state run from the income.

        Welfare under such a system wouldn’t ,philosophically, be a handout given as charity by the rich but rather your personal share of the income from shared resources.

        it has heavy communist feel in terms of philosophy of ownership of land but otherwise is totally market based and capitalist just from throwing out part of a single premise.

    • BBA says:
      October 18, 2016 at 6:39 pm

      Huh. I was just about to link John Quiggin making roughly the same point. If you think government is illegitimate and shouldn’t interfere with your property, but you only have title to your property because you acquired it from the government (or from someone else who did, etc.), then how can you call it yours?

      • dragnubbit says:
        October 19, 2016 at 1:16 am

        Yep. the social contract does not require or even request your signature. It just is. Your choices at this point are pretty much restricted to venue shopping and political activism within established institutions.

        Too much of this just seems like people thinking they took the red pill and can see the Matrix for what it is and so must either fight it or create their own. The real world is still another level beyond. If these people are as smart as they think they are, it could probably use them. Take the blue pill. The red pill is really just a psychoactive trip.

        • The Nybbler says:
          October 19, 2016 at 11:19 am

          A contract that I am bound by that does not require my agreement is not a contract by any reasonable definition of the word. Calling it a “contract” is merely an attempt to cast coercion as co-operation.

          (This is not the only problem with the “social contract”; being enforceable only by one side, and changeable at will by that side, are other issues)

          • Anonymous says:
            October 19, 2016 at 11:25 am

            That’s all well and good, but for some strange reason libertarians always refuse to acknowledge that the same logic applies to “property rights”.

          • Jiro says:
            October 19, 2016 at 4:38 pm

            Applying the logic to property rights doesn’t help non-libertarians. If this calls the property owner’s property right into question, it also calls the government’s property right into question for exactly the same reasons. In other words, you can’t use this reasoning to shift the ownership from the individual to the government.

          • Anonymous says:
            October 19, 2016 at 5:40 pm

            Non-libertarians don’t need the help. Their philosophy isn’t the one that if enacted would produce total anarchy (in the pejorative sense).

            The critique is effective because libertarians are happy to blithely throw away almost anything they haven’t personally consented to and somehow think everything will just work itself out. Except that they tend have a visceral attachment to very strong property rights and so can’t stand to see the same argument applied there.

            Pointing out that ‘I never agreed not to walk on the land that you claim is yours’ follows quite straightforwardly from ‘I never agreed to pay property taxes’ is not intended to say we should accept neither but rather that we should accept both. However if someone is willing to bite that bullet I’d at least give him points for consistency.

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 19, 2016 at 9:00 pm

            @Nybbler

            Society gave you advantages before you could even pay for them or even contemplate them. It gave you a system with protected freedoms and property rights though you did nothing to merit such consideration. Yes it is a forced exchange with an imaginary entity (society) – its just a metaphor. But your gratitude is not necessary for the terms to be binding.

          • The Nybbler says:
            October 19, 2016 at 11:34 pm

            @dragnubbit

            It’s metaphor, but it’s a terrible metaphor because it misses the essential points of a contract. It’s a forced exchange where the terms are dictated by one side, may only be enforced by that side, and may be changed at any time by that side. It’s almost but not quite entirely unlike a contract.

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 20, 2016 at 2:09 am

            @Nybbler

            I did not invent the metaphor. But with two words I can reference 100’s of years of political writing on the idea of obligations towards your host society. Saves me typing.

          • IrishDude says:
            October 20, 2016 at 7:53 am

            @dragnubbit

            Just because someone does something nice for you doesn’t mean you owe them something. If my neighbor mows my lawn for me without my permission and leaves a bill at my door, I’m under no obligation to pay and he has no right to coerce me for payment. Similarly, if my neighbor starts patrolling the neighborhood to keep crime down he has no right to coerce me for payment if I didn’t request the service.

          • The Nybbler says:
            October 20, 2016 at 8:47 am

            @dragnubbit

            I’m aware you didn’t invent the concept. But 100s of years of thinking or no, there is no contract, there is only force. Thomas Hobbes thinks one should prostrate themselves to the sovereign in abject gratitude for not being left in a state of nature, and maybe he’s right, but that doesn’t make the situation at all like a contract.

          • Aapje says:
            October 20, 2016 at 9:17 am

            @The Nybbler

            I think that the disconnect is that you define ‘contract’ purely as something that someone must enter into him/herself.

            However, historically, contracts have also existed that were inherited and/or opt-out, rather than opt-in. You may not consider contracts like that valid or part of your definition of the word, but it’s a bit silly to object to a debater using an established term to make a point.

          • The Nybbler says:
            October 20, 2016 at 9:41 am

            @Aapje: You could say there was a contract a person inherited which dedicated all their labor to their employer for their lifetime (and that of all their children, and their children, ad infinitum) in return for room and board. Calling this a contract rather than chattel slavery would be ridiculous, of course. And so with the social contract.

          • Aapje says:
            October 20, 2016 at 10:35 am

            Well, it would be both a contract and chattel slavery, the two can simultaneously apply (and slavery in the past did sometimes include contracts, both voluntary or not).

            Perhaps the issue is that as a non-libertarian, I don’t have automatic respect for (even voluntary) contracts, so I have no trouble judging some contracts as immoral.

            Perhaps you separate the world into voluntary contracts and obligations not personally chosen, where you claim the former to be morally superior to the latter. In that case, the world ‘social contract’ would mix up the categories that you consider distinct. However, that distinction is only valid to libertarians who value voluntary association greatly.

            In my view, pretty much no agreement is truly voluntary, as one is always picking the lesser evil based on partial information, limited by ones own ability to offer a quid for the quo and within the limitations of trying to satisfy the human self. So any contract where the personal stakes are greater than zero and where the person has less than infinite quid, only involves some freedom.

          • Dr Dealgood says:
            October 20, 2016 at 10:57 am

            @Aapje,

            Contract
            1. A written or spoken agreement, especially one concerning employment, sales, or tenancy, that is intended to be enforceable by law.

            OED Online

            The reason we have a word for “contract” in the English language is to describe a legally enforceable agreement.

            Contract law agrees that mutual assent is a necessary precondition of any valid contract:

            Now, whatever in abstract discussion may be said as to the legal notion of its being necessary, in order to the effecting of a valid and binding contract, that the minds of the parties should be brought together at one and the same moment, that notion is practically the foundation of English law upon the subject of the formation of contracts.

            The word contract is misused when it is applied to an involuntary obligation.

            That’s not to say such obligations are immoral or unreasonable, just that they are by definition never contracts.

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 20, 2016 at 3:03 pm

            Lots of words have legal meanings that are more narrow than their usage in tracts on philosophy and political science. Hence the modifying term ‘social’ on it to show it is not a typical contract. Most marriage contracts throughout human history did not involve consent of either party. Many contracts have great force and effect on people who were not party to their consummation (such as laws passed before adulthood), and they would be wise to accept that force and effect as reality if they are to make good decisions rather than pretend they are unaffected. And if you want a legal mumbo-jumbo argument (not that I feel it is necessary for the sovereignty of the state to be a fait accompli, just that those who insist on a legal ratification might take solace in it), the contract was validated by your parents on your behalf when they filed your birth certificate requesting your recognition as a new citizen. And you are likely fortunate enough to live in a country where you are free to negotiate better terms with alternate host countries and depart with very few cancellation penalties (I think a few thousand dollars to renounce if you are US).

          • suntzuanime says:
            October 20, 2016 at 4:57 pm

            I never signed anything. And if you want to tell me that even if I never signed the contract it still has force over me, you are of course correct, in the same way that a man pointing a gun at me has force over me. While I may do what the man with the gun says, I will stop short of considering that I have a *moral obligation* to do so, as I would if I had signed a contract.

            Certainly I agree that government exists! But that’s not what most people mean when they talk about the “social contract”.

        • Lumifer says:
          October 19, 2016 at 11:26 am

          Yep. the social contract does not require or even request your signature. It just is. Your choices at this point are pretty much restricted to venue shopping and political activism within established institutions.

          Boggle. So let’s apply it to, say, medieval times. You’re a serf. The social contract doesn’t require your consent, it just is (fell from heavens, most likely : -/). Your choices at this point are pretty much restricted to trying to run away to a different lord and to submitting petitions for justice “within established institutions”.

          Everything is great, isn’t it?

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 19, 2016 at 8:50 pm

            That is a pretty fair explanation of what serfs faced, and yet fails to refute my statement. The smart ones figured out how to advance within that system (or at least position their offspring to). And they did participate in the forms of political activism available in their day (riots for example). For the most part they did not form discussion groups and expect the world to change to suit their fancy, and none of those that did amounted to anything.

            Fortunately we live in times where we have substantially more political rights and avenues of action. So your example is also irrelevant.

          • Aapje says:
            October 20, 2016 at 3:53 am

            @Lumifer

            The idea is that democracy legitimizes the current social contract (and the contract being relatively consistent with universal human rights legitimizes it further).

            So despite your personal lack of consent, society as a whole did consent.

            fell from heavens, most likely

            That is actually how the contract of the time was often legitimized, as many rulers claimed to have God’s mandate.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 20, 2016 at 10:40 am

            @ dragnubbit

            Your model fails to explain why we aren’t living in feudalism any more. In fact, it fails to explain any major political upheaval in human history. I think that makes it pretty useless.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 20, 2016 at 10:48 am

            @ Aapje

            democracy legitimizes the current social contract

            As The Nybbler keeps on pointing out, this still doesn’t make it a contract and I’m not sure what is the meaning of the word “legitimize” here — do you mean “successfully persuade the majority of the population that this is How Things Should Be Done”?

            A broad social agreement about How Things Should Be Done isn’t limited to democracies, of course.

            many rulers claimed to have God’s mandate

            I’m well aware of this. Is democracy any different in claiming the Mandate of Heaven?

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 20, 2016 at 2:44 pm

            @Lumifer

            Serfs did not end feudalism. Competition between elites who had different centers of power and motivations did (royalty, gentry, burgers and priests). There was not some grand people’s revolution. Mainly it was just the concentration of royal power and the attitudes and actions of disorganized peasantry were only tangential to the process.

            The only ‘model’ I am proposing is to understand that the concept of the sovereign nation-state with a monopoly on violence is not some historical accident that can be reprogrammed, and that working within institutions has nearly always been the best way to leverage your ideas into tangible results. Failure to influence said institutions may say more about the feasibility of your agenda in the real world than theoretical musings about how property rights are somehow orthogonal to the state despite all real-world evidence to the contrary.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 20, 2016 at 3:18 pm

            @ dragnubbit

            the concept of the sovereign nation-state with a monopoly on violence is not some historical accident that can be reprogrammed

            And who is it that you are arguing against, the one who claims the sovereign nation-state was a historical accident?

            working within institutions has nearly always been the best way to leverage your ideas into tangible results

            That… depends. For incremental change, probably. For massive, revolutionary change, not so.

            The changes in society are basically bimodal: most are small, utilize the existing system, and keep it intact. But their effect is small is well. Occasionally you have a change that sweeps away the existing system and institutes something else in its place. These are rare, but their effect is huge.

            See e.g. Taleb on the role of outliers.

            Failure to influence said institutions may say more about the feasibility of your agenda in the real world

            Again, in the common case, yes (“The fact that some geniuses were laughed at does not imply that all who are laughed at are geniuses”). However once in a while you will have outliers — Karl Marx is a good example — who will reshape the landscape.

          • Aapje says:
            October 21, 2016 at 2:38 am

            @Lumifer

            I’m not sure what is the meaning of the word “legitimize” here — do you mean “successfully persuade the majority of the population that this is How Things Should Be Done”?

            If you can persuade people to vote for a certain system, I’d argue that it has more legitimacy than a system where a minority chooses the system & the people relatively freely choose not to revolt and that in turn has more legitimacy than when the people are severely oppressed to keep them from revolting.

            Of course, for a hardcore technocrat/monarchist, support by the populace is meaningless.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 21, 2016 at 10:36 am

            @ Aapje

            I’m trying to go meta here. “Legitimize”, technically speaking, means “make legal” which implies that there is some law standing above the situation. In the case of political systems there is no higher law, so the question is which yardstick we apply and where did we get this yardstick from.

            Another issue here is that the dominant (at the moment) political system will tell you as a matter of fact that the values which make it the best are, of course, the most legitimate and moral ones.

    • Tekhno says:
      October 18, 2016 at 6:47 pm

      I’m making a another thread so not to veer off topic, but something someone said in the discussions above that made me want to discuss something else:

      Um… I wish the edit function was still active. I have a habit of writing one thing, and then thinking better off it and going back to the beginning to start writing again without completely erasing the old stuff, producing a barely legible chimera sentence.

      I meant to say: I’m making another thread so as not to veer off topic, but something someone said in the discussions above made me want to discuss something else:

      • Nancy Lebovitz says:
        October 18, 2016 at 7:23 pm

        I can still edit a comment for an hour after I post it. Chrome on a laptop.

        • Fahundo says:
          October 19, 2016 at 12:26 pm

          Me too. Works on Internet Explorer at work and Opera at home.

    • Mark V Anderson says:
      October 18, 2016 at 9:52 pm

      Tekhno — I’m a little confused by your comments. You say that NAP might be violated by property ownership because tracing back ownership may ultimately lead to a violent taking. But how could most property be traced back to violence? Almost everything I own I received through trading my own labor for it. And the ones I have bought property from mostly used their own labor to buy it, eventually traced back to the one who made the property. I don’t get what you mean.

      The only property that can truly be traced back to violence in that way is land, because land was never created by anyone, but was simply appropriated at some point. But if you treat land in that way, you are simply in the already established ideology of Georgism. Georgism proponents are essentially libertarians about everything but land. They believe land should belong to the government, and government revenue should be composed exclusively of land rents. Yes, this is ideologically very sweet, and I would think that many deontological libertarians would take this approach as a matter of principle. It is impractical for various reasons, but that has never stopped the more ideological libertarians in the past. Although I lean libertarian, I do for consequentialist reasons, and I don’t believe in NAP. So for me it isn’t an issue.

      • Murphy says:
        October 19, 2016 at 9:47 am

        I think part of the idea is that if the land is tainted then so are the raw materials extracted from it. Sure you built that anvil with your own 2 hands but the land that you got the ore from was stolen by your great great granddad when he butchered all the people who used to live there.

        So it could also relate to how far the taint of violent acquisition spreads.

        • David Friedman says:
          October 19, 2016 at 7:26 pm

          I think the answer to that is that if you used your labor to make something using inputs some of which were stolen from a now unknown owner you have a better claim to that something than anyone else, since it is partly yours and not partly anyone else’s we know of.

          • Mark V Anderson says:
            October 19, 2016 at 10:21 pm

            @David Friedman. Yes, I’ve heard that theory before. But does that mean that if I buy some land and just camp out on it, I don’t really own it? Or more commonly, if I buy a house, and only apply a small amount of labor to it, then I don’t effectively own it? I’ve certainly never heard anyone make such an argument in real life. It seems to me that the case of land is simply one area that libertarians accept that practicality rules, because the Georgist philosophy has too many practical problems.

          • Murphy says:
            October 20, 2016 at 9:24 am

            Sure, but that comes down to how much taint of violent acquisition you’re willing to accept.

            Accept a lot of taint and you just need to pass things through a layer of obfuscation to whitewash them. Some take the position that as soon as it reaches the hands of someone who bought it in good faith it’s theirs even if it was previously stolen and the original owner is stuck with the problem of tracking down the thief.

            Accept very very little and almost nobody has any valid claims.

  5. Jaskologist says:
    October 18, 2016 at 2:50 pm

    Study from 2012 now corrected to show liberals, not conservatives, more authoritarian

    “In line with our expectations, [Psychoticism] (positively related to tough-mindedness and authoritarianism) is associated with social conservatism and conservative military attitudes,” the study said.

    The study also posited those who are socially liberal are more likely to possess behaviors associated with “Social Desirability,” or the desire to get along with others, than those who are socially conservative.

    But in an erratum issued by the journal, first reported by Retraction Watch, the authors said those two findings were “exactly reversed.”

    “Thus, where we indicated that higher scores in Table 1 (page 40) reflect a more conservative response, they actually reflect a more liberal response,” the authors said. “Specifically, in the original manuscript, the descriptive analyses report that those higher in Eysenck’s psychoticism are more conservative, but they are actually more liberal; and where the original manuscript reports those higher in neuroticism and social desirability are more liberal, they are, in fact, more conservative.”

    I believe everything that correction just said, because it’s exactly what I wanted to hear.

    • Incurian says:
      October 18, 2016 at 4:04 pm

      They are both authoritarian, they just have different targets. And social science research is a dumpster fire.

    • pku says:
      October 18, 2016 at 4:34 pm

      Social science is unreliable, but I’d agree with the conclusion that neither the right nor the left are strictly more authoritarian – as political polarization becomes more of a cultural divide than a rational decision, both sides get more heterogeneous in terms of the personalities involved (since the “more authoritarian” side loses the ability to recruit the other side’s authoritarian-leaning people).

      Bleh. Authoritarian is hard to spell.

  6. onyomi says:
    October 18, 2016 at 11:04 am

    Reading Sam Francis: “Beautiful Losers: Essays on the Failure of American Conservatism” and thinking about this idea: is it not enough merely to have a good idea if there is no concentrated interest group whom it benefits to take it up as a cause? Related, if there is a strong enough interest in pursuing something (e. g. monetary policy), will a thinker to provide intellectual ammunition for it (e. g. Keynes) inevitably show up? Is Marx more correct than Mises in this instance that material needs, wants, and interests trump ideas?

    • dndnrsn says:
      October 18, 2016 at 11:45 am

      Does a group have to benefit materially to back a cause? To link that to the second question – the existence of affluent Marxists would contradict economic determinism.

            October 18, 2016 at 5:22 pm

    • Two McMillion says:
      October 18, 2016 at 1:23 pm

      is it not enough merely to have a good idea if there is no concentrated interest group whom it benefits to take it up as a cause?

      Yes, but “benefits” can be broader than you might initially imagine. “I strongly believe in this principle and intend to pursue it” counts as a benefit for these purposes.

    • Anonymous Bosch says:
      October 18, 2016 at 2:16 pm

      Reading Sam Francis: “Beautiful Losers: Essays on the Failure of American Conservatism” and thinking about this idea: is it not enough merely to have a good idea if there is no concentrated interest group whom it benefits to take it up as a cause?

      3rd generation nuclear power seems to be a fitting example. The left is beholden to the environmentalist fantasy of a direct transition from fossil fuels to renewables and gives no rhetorical support beyond the occasional token reference in an “all of the above” policy. The right will give very shallow rhetorical support but in practice has zero interest in doing anything that might threaten the dominance of fossil fuels (such as a carbon tax on coal/gas, or a French-style subsidy push). The amount of physical fuel required is relatively small so the extractive industries don’t have an interest group of workers. Same with running the plants; global nuclear power generation has been basically static for 15 years and the up-front costs make it hard to pitch from an economic growth standpoint (especially compared to the NIMBY effect).

    • dragnubbit says:
      October 18, 2016 at 2:18 pm

      American politics is becoming more plebian, not less. Both major parties remain beholden to public opinion despite what cynics might claim, and the primary process in both major parties is quite accessible for different proposed directions to compete. Ideas can and do win primaries because tribalism is a second-order effect. If Burke-ians are failing to resonate with Republican primary voters, it is not because there are not enough moneyed elites to fund it or that the system is rigged. It is that even Republicans want big government to fix their lives. The diffused opinions and revealed preferences of voters are beating the concentrated interests of Republican thought-leaders (such as on free trade and immigration reform).

      • Lumifer says:
        October 18, 2016 at 2:30 pm

        “Democracy is the theory that the common people know what they want, and deserve to get it good and hard.” — H. L. Mencken

      • Lumifer says:

        People discovered that they can bullshit their way to tenure.

      • dragnubbit says:
        October 18, 2016 at 2:46 pm

        The hiring pool got expanded beyond white males from a certain social strata. Those doing the hiring slowly started become more diverse in both their own background and preferred candidates. Customers began judging schools on their faculty demographics.

        The question now is what could reverse the trend? I think you use the same antidote as before, which is sunshine. Publish data on faculty political leanings (using whatever sources are available) at the granularity of institution. Activate conservative students to make this an issue. If it matters to customers, then there will be pressure on schools to protect, cultivate and seek out more conservative faculty members.

        This approach may be too distasteful for some on the right to endorse as tactically it is very leftist. The right wing solution is to let the advantage right-wing-leaning faculties should have on an undervalued pool of talent and an under-served market of customers to win in the marketplace.

        • dndnrsn says:
          October 18, 2016 at 3:26 pm

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 18, 2016 at 3:43 pm

            Agreed. Not saying it is entirely demographic, just that it provided a major kickstart that might explain a rapid shift. Cultural factors at some point create a sustainable feedback cycle.

        • The original Mr. X says:

          That would work if academia just went from being more right-wing than the general population to having the same politics as the general population. I’m not sure why it would account for academia becoming notably more left-wing than the country as a whole.

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:38 am

            Why should academia, which is its own subculture, automatically reflect or even naturally trend to the political leanings of the entire population? Plenty of subcultures generate feedback loops that make them distinctive in political leanings from the country-wide average. Both by appearing unwelcome to deviants, by creating an information and discussion bubble, as well as confirmation bias about who is smart and who is naive. Isn’t this the message board that periodically wonders why left-leaning people rarely stick around and loves to construct strawmen about modern Marxism?

          • Aapje says:
            October 19, 2016 at 2:35 am

            Why should academia, which is its own subculture, automatically reflect or even naturally trend to the political leanings of the entire population?

            If you look at the repercussions (reduced Overton window, lack of debate/pushback on certain topics, a loss of faith by people who do not feel part of that subculture). there are good reasons why it ought not be like this.

            Plenty of subcultures generate feedback loops that make them distinctive in political leanings from the country-wide average.

            The difference is that science is supposedly a primarily scientific field, not a political or social one.

            Isn’t this the message board that periodically wonders why left-leaning people rarely stick around and loves to construct strawmen about modern Marxism?

            Yet this is just one forum out of gazillions. In science, more and more there is just one kind of forum.

          • Anonymous says:

        • Anonymous says:
          October 18, 2016 at 6:44 pm

          So what you’re syaing is… the Enlightenment can only be sustained by restricting access to its instruments to upper-middle-class men?

          • dragnubbit says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:39 am

      • David Friedman says:
        October 18, 2016 at 9:05 pm

        I don’t know about what happened twenty years ago, but Nozick has an interesting explanation of why universities tend to be left–probably written earlier than that.

        In high school, you experience two status systems. One, status among students, is decentralized, based on looks, social skills, and the like. One, grades, is centralized. People who do better in the former end up liking decentralized systems such as the market, so end up on the right. People who do better in the latter end up liking centralized systems, end up on the left. The latter group have good grades, like the academic status system, become professors. The former group become businessmen.

        • cassander says:
          October 18, 2016 at 10:24 pm

          If I were going to go with that sort of structural explanation, I’d be far more inclined to go with something like centralized solutions, at least those advocated by most academics, just happen to involve putting academics and experts at the top of the social pyramid, and others do not. I used to joke that the dream of every academic was to be the guy in the opening scene of a disaster movie, the guy who gets the called in to speak with the president and told that his previously obscure work is the key to saving the world. The joke was less funny funny after the crimea invasion, when I heard Russia and Eurasia express that sentiment almost literally.

          That said, and I might have said this to you before, I think it’s a mistake to credit either the left or the right with being inherently enthusiastic about markets. markets make both sides uncomfortable,though for different reasons. PEople confident in their power like centralized solutions, people worried their enemies are stronger than them push for decentralized.

          • Anonymous says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:00 am

            Russia and Eurasia express

            R&E experts?

          • cassander says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:12 am

            Bah, can’t even blame that one on autocorrect. Yes, experts.

          • The original Mr. X says:
            October 19, 2016 at 10:00 am

            when I heard Russia and Eurasia express that sentiment almost literally.

            Russia is at war with Eurasia. Russia has always been at war with Eurasia.

        • dndnrsn says:
          October 19, 2016 at 10:34 am

          @David Friedman: I don’t know about high school, but are grades even remotely centralized in university? I recall them varying widely based on who was marking them – to the point that during undergrad I gave up on trying to find correlations between what I was doing beyond the most obvious stuff (getting my facts right, spelling and grammar, etc) and my marks. I’d work hard on something and get a 70, or churn out some real crap while half-sober and get a 90. It was different in grad school.

          I did have a TA once admit that they were under centralized pressure not to give out too many high marks – kind of an unofficial curve – but besides that it seemed like it varied wildly.

          • David Friedman says:
            October 19, 2016 at 7:22 pm

            My guess is that Nozick was thinking mostly about K-12, but I read the essay a long time ago and am going on memory.

    • Nancy Lebovitz says:
      October 18, 2016 at 10:54 am

      So should white men quit complaining about social justice because people get stronger as a result of challenges?

    • onyomi says:
      October 18, 2016 at 12:52 pm

      He makes a good point related to what I’m talking about below re. political ideas and those whom they benefit: if you produce a piece of research, statistic, etc. which is congenial to the goals of some group, then even if it swiftly and thoroughly debunked, people will continue to cite it for decades and decades.

The only question is whether or not it’s unprincipled to vote for Hillary when you’d prefer Jill or Bernie.

  8. Kevin C. says:
    October 18, 2016 at 7:39 am

    Any thoughts here on the “science decolonizers”/#ScienceMustFall at University of Cape Town?

    Essentially, these students believe that modern scientific understanding is too Eurocentric. One explained:

    “I have a question for all the science people. There is a place in KZN called Umhlab’uyalingana. They believe that through the magic’ you call it black magic’ they call it witchcraft’ you are able to send lightening to strike someone. Can you explain that scientifically because it’s something that happens?”

    Many people laughed at this remark because, well, witchcraft is not something that happens. But according to the student, witchcraft is like Isaac Newton’s theory of gravity—it’s just one way of explaining the world, among many.

    “Decolonising the science would mean doing away with it entirely and starting all over again to deal with how we respond to the environment and how we understand it,” the student continued.

    Cultural relativism gone too far? To much “decolonialization” rhetoric? Or just college students being college students.

    • Lumifer says:
      October 18, 2016 at 8:27 am

      Stupid people are stupid.

    • Dr Dealgood says:
      October 18, 2016 at 8:35 am

      It’s just more postmodernist garbage. This happened before, in the nineties “science wars,” and seems like it will keep happening for quite some time.

      Critical theory is too politically useful to the elites for it to go anywhere, while by the same token science is too practically useful to risk hamstringing it. So for the moment the two are going to end up sharing a lot of the same space.

      • Anonymous says:
        October 18, 2016 at 10:34 am

        I miss when being Leftist meant that you were opposed to stupid anti-scientific religious claims.

        When was this? During the heyday of forced sterilization for social progress? Lysenkoism? The Great Leap Forward? Second-wave feminism? Third-wave feminism?

        • lvlln says:
          October 18, 2016 at 11:11 am

          Probably referring to things like evolution vs. creationism or climate science vs. climate science denial, where leftists have been on the side of science and opposed to stupid anti-scientific religious claims for a while now.

          I grew up in a time when those were major talking points, and I ended up internalizing the idea that the left was the pro-science side of the political spectrum.

          Sadly, incidents like this and the recent rise of SJWs has taught me that I was completely and utterly mistaken. Perhaps we’re just better at using academia to obscure our science denialism. One hopes that as the science denial becomes more blatant like that video, more people get disillusioned.

          • David Friedman says:
            October 18, 2016 at 8:58 pm

            I think the usual pattern, left and right, is to support science when it produces the conclusions you like, oppose it when it doesn’t.

            The left has been generally hostile to the evidence that intelligence is to a significant degree heritable for quite a long time. More generally, fundamentalists on the right say they don’t believe in evolution. People on the left say they do believe in evolution but then make arguments that imply they don’t.

            My standard example is the argument from women having a different distribution of outcomes from men to the conclusion that they are being discriminated against. That assumes that there are no significant innate differences. But evolution implies that we are as if designed for reproductive success, males and females differ precisely in their role in reproduction, so it would be surprising if the same distribution of characteristics was optimal for both.

          • Aapje says:
            October 19, 2016 at 3:57 am

            But evolution implies that we are as if designed for reproductive success, males and females differ precisely in their role in reproduction, so it would be surprising if the same distribution of characteristics was optimal for both.

            It’s not even necessary to make a theoretical assertion here, the proof of biological differences between the sexes is undeniable:
            – Penis & flat chest vs vagina & breasts
            – Men are clearly much stronger on average

            So the only reasonable argument that can be had is the extent to which the sexes differ, not that they do.

            Although what I find amusing, is that a major disagreement that I have with the mainstream left, is that I clearly believe that men & women differ less than they do. Unlike me, they generally seem to believe that all gender differences are taught. However, they are generally so convinced that people cannot resist this programming, that it seems to me that their position is indistinguishable from believing in huge natural differences. When they are willing to discriminate against men just for being men, without actual evidence that those men are ‘nurtured’ into toxic masculinity, it just ends up being discrimination that is indistinguishable from discrimination based on a belief in natural differences.

          • lvlln says:
            October 19, 2016 at 9:42 am

            @Aapje

            That phenomenon to me seems to be part of a misunderstanding of science. A misunderstanding that I think is willful. They don’t understand or seem to want to understand that there’s no reason to believe that any given individual in a category has any characteristics generally attributed to that category. That in humans, virtually no non-trivial or non-definitional characteristic has an incidence rate of 100%. How often do you see statements of the sort “Men tend to have greater upper body strength than women” responded with “But what about that woman Olympian who can lift 450lbs? Checkmate, misogynist!”

            So when they see a man, they don’t see an individual who may or may not have various characteristics that are common in men, they see all those characteristics grouped together manifested in human form. Same goes for women, whites, Asians, etc. This seems to me to be the major failing of privilege theory that dominate far left social discourse right now. It’s very clearly the creationism/AGW denial of the left.

          • lvlln says:
            October 19, 2016 at 9:58 am

            @David Friedman

            I think you may be generally right, though I think the statement “People on the left say they do believe in evolution but then make arguments that imply they don’t” isn’t quite right. It’s more like, they make arguments that imply that they don’t understand evolution. It’s like how someone can believe that AGW is happening while also mistakenly believing that protecting the ozone layer will significantly help to stop or slow down AGW. Evolution is just some idea in biology that they know is True, they don’t bother with learning the actual details and exact implications.

            With respect to denial of m/f biological differences – and HBD-denial in general – I think it comes from basically an overactive immune response to recent atrocities that were partially justified by arguments about biological differences. To protect against that, they’ve taken as dogma the unproven assertion that there are no biological differences between humans of different categories, at least when it comes to categories that they consider valuable (as an aside, the idea that HBD doesn’t at all imply that any given individual has any less moral worth than any other individual doesn’t seem to occur to them – that THAT’S where bigotry needs to be argued against and stopped and snuffed out, not in the facts which should be empirically determined).

            Considering the level of those atrocities, such a strong immune response isn’t entirely unjustified. But when it manifests in outright science denial, it’s harmful and (hopefully) unsustainable. I think we’re beginning to see it breaking down. I hope, anyway.

          • dndnrsn says:
            October 19, 2016 at 10:18 am

            @lvlln:

            I don’t think you can ascribe that to left-wing politics. It’s a super-common fallacy that starts very early, right along with “you don’t like this music? Well I mean it’s not like YOU are on the radio!” It’s a basic human problem – we assign more value to individual examples than to statistics.

          • lvlln says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:51 pm

            @dndnrsn

            I’m not ascribing it to leftist politics, at least not in the sense that it’s unique or particular to leftist politics. Yes, it’s super common, and IMHO rightist politics suffer from it even more, and in more areas. That doesn’t make leftists committing and encouraging this fallacy any less harmful.

          • dndnrsn says:
            October 19, 2016 at 12:57 pm

            I think it’s not something that needs politics to exist, even. It is unfortunate that it gets promoted though.

          • Aapje says:
            October 19, 2016 at 7:04 pm

            @lvlln

            I think that a defining aspect is that it is collectivist. There is a denial that people have free will to make their own decisions and are instead merely pawns controlled by greater forces. As such, people are collectively guilty or collectively victimized; depending on the grouping that is believed to define them. A popular statement among the regressive left is ‘[oppressed group] cannot be [-ist] against [oppressor group], which illustrates the black/white dichotomy. Of course, the logical corollary is that ‘[oppressor group] is always [-ist] against [oppressed group]’. This is often expressed by claiming that the ‘oppressor group’ cannot avoid having privilege, which is a vague term that motte-and-baileys between benefits that others give a ‘privileged’ person and bad behavior by that person him/herself.

            If you dig into social justice thinkers, there are very strong links to communism, which makes similar collective judgments, but on class, rather than gender/race/etc.

            IMO, collectivist thinking is very dangerous, as it is an enabler of horrible treatment of people ‘for the greater good.’

    • Nicholas says:
      October 18, 2016 at 4:54 pm

      It’s the impulse behind “teaching the controversy” about young earth creationism, but channeled through a pagan instead of a Baptist.

      • Anon. says:
        October 18, 2016 at 5:06 pm

        Of course, pagans are famous for their religious creeds focusing on decolonization and anti-eurocentrism.

        • BBA says:
          October 18, 2016 at 8:33 pm

          Right now Christianity is closely associated with the Right and all other religious views are associated with the Left. The arguments follow accordingly. (I’ve seen some shifts towards Islam = Left, non-Islam = Right but we aren’t there yet.)

    • BBA says:
      October 18, 2016 at 7:12 pm

      I wonder how many of these students came to these beliefs sincerely, versus how many are just looking for something new to rebel against. It’s one thing if you’ve been taught witchcraft at home and physics in school, and you don’t trust schools – they were teaching lies in other subjects under apartheid not too long ago. It’s another thing if you only discovered witchcraft from your classmates at the university, and figure that because it’s not European it must be right.

    • Skef says:
      October 18, 2016 at 8:48 pm

      I have what I expect are the same views as most people here about what is likely true and false and how to go about evaluating claims. But really, why wouldn’t most South Africans be in a fucked up epistemic state right now? Why wouldn’t they feel the need to go back to something like first principles, with all the messiness that implies?

      Give them some time to work things out for themselves.

      • Lumifer says:
        October 18, 2016 at 8:57 pm

        But really, why wouldn’t most South Africans be in a fucked up epistemic state right now?

        Um, and what’s special about South Africa “right now”?

        • Skef says:
          October 18, 2016 at 10:27 pm

          The recentness with respect to cultural change of Apartheid?

          Should we rehash here all the screwed-up attitudes about the civil war that remain 150 years on?

          • Lumifer says:
            October 18, 2016 at 10:58 pm

            Sure. Tell me how the recentness of apartheid (and the people in the video sure don’t look like they are old enough to have experienced it) makes you deny science. Bonus points if the same explanation applies to slavery 150 years ago.

            Double bonus points if the explanation naturally doesn’t apply to Jews who were segregated and discriminated against until the end of WW2, more or less.

          • Skef says:
            October 18, 2016 at 11:49 pm

            You have a different understanding of the Weimar Republic than I do.

            Anyway, your question is the wrong place to start. Why don’t you offer a brief explanation of why an American with a typical high-school education accepts “science” given the equations they’ve learned and the few dozen experiments they’ve performed or witnessed.

            A hint: it’s not because of those classes.

          • JayT says:
            October 18, 2016 at 11:59 pm

            I would guess the main reason the average American high schooler accepts science is because they are told it is just so, but I would guess almost an equal reason is that they see what science gives them (eg, iPhones, the internet, space shuttles, etc).

          • Skef says:
            October 19, 2016 at 1:22 am

            JayT: Seems about right to me.

            My basic point is that when the people (broadly speaking) telling you that science is correct are the same ones who thought Apartheid was an appropriate framework for your family to live under as recently as the 90s that puts you in a shitty epistemic situation. That kind of cultural trust in institutions has to be rebuilt internally through investigation. There need to be people you feel you can look to for such answers and those people need to be giving the answers in question.

            The woman in the video is calling for a kind of pluralism of explanation about an issue that *we* have good evidence from past investigations does not call for pluralism. I see no reason that evidence won’t eventually be convincing for most folks in this movement. But I refuse to look at actual black South Africans in 2016 who have this kind of attitude in the same way as someone in the U.S. who wants to “decolonize” their chemistry department. I would expect the latter person to have some explanation for their lack of cultural charity and for them to apply it non-selectively.

            [The point about technology is relevant, but of course people have experience of technology working in their everyday lives. One could even maintain an “I’m suspicious of this but it’s still too useful to set aside for now” attitude about things like smartphones. And anyway a tentative expectation of plural explanations wouldn’t necessarily call for alternate explanations of specific bits of technology.]

          • Anon. says:
            October 19, 2016 at 7:00 am

            My basic point is that when the people (broadly speaking) telling you that science is correct are the same ones who thought Apartheid was an appropriate framework for your family to live under as recently as the 90s that puts you in a shitty epistemic situation.

            …where do you think they get leftism from? Do you think “decolonization” and “anti-eurocentrism” are indigenous ideologies? These things are pushed by the (broadly speaking) same people who colonized them in the first place.

          • Sandy says:
            October 19, 2016 at 7:08 am

            I don’t think “decolonization” is something the West pushes; colonized people have resisted colonization for centuries, be it physical or cultural. The whole idea that there are “Western” models of science rather than universal methods and truths might be something pushed by Western academia, however.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 19, 2016 at 10:56 am

            @ Skef

            We… have a radically different idea of science. You think that science and trust in science is based on “cultural trust in institutions” which may or may not be lacking. I think that science and trust in science is based on things working, empirically, in real life.

            I don’t expect people to trust science because a high priest of science tells them so — high priests spout a great deal of gibberish. I expect people to trust science because it produce results: it gives them a metal contraption which kills people at a distance, it gives them a box which stays cold inside, it gives them a pill which cures their sickness.

            And that’s without going into all the other problems with your theory, starting with asking which scientific institution exactly told these young people (and not their parents or grandparents) that apartheid is how science says one should organize the society; and ending with pointing out that most of their ideology comes from dead white men, anyway.

          • Alex says:
            October 19, 2016 at 11:17 am

            Lumifer:

            You have science and engineering confused?!

          • Lumifer says:
            October 19, 2016 at 11:21 am

            @ Alex

            No, I don’t.

          • nimim. k.m. says:
            October 20, 2016 at 12:56 am

            @Lumifer

            >I don’t expect people to trust science because a high priest of science tells them so — high priests spout a great deal of gibberish. I expect people to trust science because it produce results: it gives them a metal contraption which kills people at a distance, it gives them a box which stays cold inside, it gives them a pill which cures their sickness.

            Check your expectations. Most people don’t operate on this level: they take the boxes and pills; and yet continue to believe whatever they find convenient to keep on believing. I have no idea what they primarily trust, but it’s probably more the “doctors who wear white doctor outfits” than independent thought about benefits of medical science.

            Anecdote. One of the top students in my class during secondary school (consistently very good marks in all science subjects, biology, chemistry, physics, etc — which should give some background knowledge about how science operates, in ideal world) was also very non-critical about chakras and reiki and homeopathy. “It just works!”

            Another anecdote. I have a relative who is an engineer and creates and applies lots of scientific knowledge about mechanics, electricity, and so on, and remains totally oblivious to anything in so far as it does not agree with his preconceived notions (ranging from evolution-denial to “gay is evil sickness” and “all members of certain races are stupider than me”).

            Most the people I know or have known in past don’t think about science very much, let alone trust it.They just do whatever is the normal thing to do in their social group, like buy an iPhone and treat it (like everything electronic) a bit like a magical apparatus, go to a doctor when they are sick, buy whatever “health stuff” their friends eat, be worried about “radiation”, and are “totally a Pisces because that’s just like me”. They say whether they believe in evolution depending on stuff like what their friends believe, if they go to church and what political party they vote for, and certainly don’t understand how it actually works in either case.

          • Paul Brinkley says:
            October 20, 2016 at 8:44 am

            nimim’s observations about chakras, evolution, and astrology seem actually consistent to me with Lumifer’s about empiricism.

            The top student believes in giving the right answer on school tests. A mechanical engineer believes in mechanical principles. Scientists believe in their research. These yield empirical results – the high grades come, the gears turn, and the research results in grants.

            Belief in evolution, by contrast, doesn’t yield any empirical results except for entomologists, epidemiologists, etc.; believe in primate evolution yields results for fewer still. For those for whom it does not, rejection of that belief yields little more than taunts from people who weren’t on their side anyway. Similar results obtain from belief in astrology, faith healing, ghosts, aliens, and so on.

            If there’s nothing physically or emotionally testing them, people’s beliefs tend to just calcify and accrete structure from confirmation. At this point, I’d expect most people to have a very sophisticated empirical belief in the mechanics of ingroups and outgroups.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 20, 2016 at 10:58 am

            @ nimim. k.m.

            Most people don’t operate on this level: they take the boxes and pills; and yet continue to believe whatever they find convenient to keep on believing.

            Yes, but the important point is that these people do not disbelieve science. They combine science with magical thinking (astrology, etc.) and don’t worry about contradictions. If you ask them whether science works, they will tell you that of course it works.

            The South African students take a very different position — they say that science is the white man’s tool of oppression and should be discarded or at least re-evaluated from scratch to make it conform to their ideology. They don’t want to just add witchcraft to science, they want to abandon science.

    • Agronomous says:
      October 21, 2016 at 11:15 pm

      So set up a trial: each side puts forth a target person. The Witchcraft side gets to call a curse of lightning down on the Science side’s target. The Science side gets to take the Witchcraft side’s target and tie them to a tall metal structure on top of a tall building during a thunderstorm. Whichever side’s guy lives wins.

      Of course, N=1 isn’t very convincing, so keep repeating the trials until you run out of Witchcraft supporters.

          • Anonymous says:

          • Nancy Lebovitz says:
            October 18, 2016 at 7:08 pm

            A woman told me about getting her husband drunk during the superbowl so he’d have unprotected sex with her. She wanted a child. He didn’t.

            She told me this as a funny story because her son was a sports fan.

            I asked her how her husband took it. She looked sad and said it might have had something to do with their divorce. My impression was that this was the first time she’d thought about it from that angle.

            siderea (someone I link to occasionally here) has suggested to me that one of the reasons men have trouble understanding consent is that they’re assumed to not have the right to turn down sex with conventionally attractive women. What do you think about the theory?

          • Anonymous says:
            October 18, 2016 at 7:49 pm

            Nancy, did you mean to post that comment here, or in the consent thread? I suppose that it might relevant to why people think better of statutory rape of males than of females.

            Your anecdote is directly opposed to Sidera’s theory. It is entirely about the fact that men have the right to turn down sex, at least unprotected sex. Maybe it demonstrates that women have the right to trick men, but that is a separate issue.

            Is Sidera’s theory relevant to statutory rape? I think not. The whole point of statutory rape is society punishes the adult to avoid having to deal with whether the minor consents. That the boy will consent to sex, or just go along with it because he doesn’t have the right to say no, is exactly the situation in which it would be necessary to punish the adult woman. It would be more relevant if instead of men not having the right to turn down sex, it were instead that men didn’t have the right to not want sex, either prospectively or retrospectively.

          • Lumifer says:
            October 18, 2016 at 8:35 pm

            @ Nancy Lebovitz

            they’re assumed to not have the right to turn down sex with conventionally attractive women

            I think men know they have the right, but they assume (generally speaking, correctly) that turning down sex is a major insult to the woman.
